<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 168, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[617, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 902, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|> 9702/31 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 699, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 890, 605]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 712, 904, 839]]<|/det|>

<pre>You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 99, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 103, 735, 121]]<|/det|>
1 In this experiment, you will investigate the oscillation of masses on springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 532, 152]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with masses and springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 468, 183]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 195, 824, 526]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 540, 532, 556]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 570, 144, 587]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 570, 672, 587]]<|/det|>
(a) Ensure the bottoms of both masses are at the same level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 602, 887, 618]]<|/det|>
· Pull both masses down through a short distance and release them at the same time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 633, 918, 664]]<|/det|>
· Watch the oscillations of the masses. The masses initially oscillate in phase, then out of phase and then back in phase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 680, 918, 712]]<|/det|>
· The number of oscillations of mass S from release until the masses are back in phase for the first time is \(n_{0}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 726, 406, 742]]<|/det|>
Determine and record \(n_{0}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 852, 918, 870]]<|/det|>
<form>\(n_{0}=\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 76, 185, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 74, 672, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) (i) - Add a mass of 30 g to mass S . The added mass is \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 106, 322, 121]]<|/det|>
- Record \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 121, 574, 138]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
M=
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 152, 918, 184]]<|/det|>
- Repeat (a). The number of oscillations of mass S from release until the masses are back in phase for the first time is \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 199, 437, 215]]<|/det|>
- Determine and record \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 325, 574, 342]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
n=
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 339, 920, 356]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 188, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 370, 356, 387]]<|/det|>
(ii) Calculate \(N\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 400, 546, 418]]<|/det|>
\[
N=n_{0}-n
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 479, 574, 496]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
N=
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(c) Vary \(M\) by changing the number of 10 g masses added to mass \(S\) and determine \(n\). Do not use \(M=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 589, 138]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have five sets of values of \(M\) and \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 918, 184]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(N\). Also include values of \(N^{3}\) to three significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 490, 918, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

(e) It is suggested that the quantities \(N\) and \(M\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 102, 556, 122]]<|/det|>

N^{3}=P M+Q
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 136, 405, 153]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 166, 680, 199]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 104, 702, 122]]<|/det|>
2 In this experiment, you will investigate the behaviour of paper on water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 591, 152]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two sheets of tracing paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 168, 144, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 166, 918, 214]]<|/det|>
(a) \(\bullet\) On one of the sheets of tracing paper, draw two identical rectangles as shown in Fig. 2.1 where \(c=4.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) and \(d=6.0 \mathrm{~cm}\). The orientation of the rectangles must be as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 230, 675, 247]]<|/det|>
